Arras is Pas-de-Calais ’ third most populous town after Calais and Boulogne-sur-Mer. The town counted 43,693 residents in 2012, with the Arras metropolitan area having a population of 124,200. Arras is located 182 kilometers (113 miles) north of Paris and can be reached in 2 hours by car and in 50 minutes by TGV.

Nord-Pas-de-Calais is divided in 2 departments: Nord and Pas-de-Calais. Arras is in the south-east part of the Pas-de-Calais department and forms the Arras district (arrondissement d'Arras in French) in the Artois, a former province of northern France.

North France. The city of Arras is the capital of the Pas-de-Calais department in northern France. Having Gallic and Gallo-Roman origins and more than 2,000 years of history, Arras is packed with heritage. In July 2005, the bell tower of Arras was classified as part of the “World Inheritance of Humanity” by UNESCO.

Arras (Dutch: Atrecht) is an attractive town in the Nord-Pas de Calais region of France. It was much fought-over in World War 1 and is mainly visited by tourists travelling from or to the nearby ports of Calais and Boulogne.
